data.title: This weekend’s live theater openings
data.text:
Boulder’s Dinner Theatre’s “The Drowsy Chaperone”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through May 13:

This musical, at once original and nostalgic, begins when a die-hard musical fan in his lonely New York apartment. When he plays his favorite cast album, a now forgotten 1928 smash hit called “The Drowsy Chaperone,” the show magically bursts to life in his room. The audience is instantly immersed in the silly tale of a celebrity bride and her uproarious wedding day, with our contemporary narrator commentating every step of the way.

Showtimes: 7 p.m. Wednesdays, 7:45 p.m. Thursdays-Saturdays; 1:30 and 7:45 p.m. Sundays (dinner service 90 minutes before).

5501 Arapahoe Ave., 303-449-6000 or bdt’s home page

PHAMALy’s “The Elephant Man”

Re-opens Friday, Feb. 24, through Sunday, Feb. 26: Denver’s acclaimed handicapped theater company presents Bernard Pomerance’s Tony-winning play based on the life of John Merrick, the horribly deformed victim of rare skin and bone diseases who lived in London during the latter part of the 19th century. He goes from the star freak attraction in traveling side shows to London society, where he evolves from an object of pity to a witty favorite of the aristocracy and literati.

Showtimes: 7:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday, 2 p.m. Sunday

At the Arvada Center, 6901 Wadsworth Blvd., Arvada, 720-898-7200 or the arvada center’s home page

Paragon’s “Miss Julie”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through March 17: Paragon moves into its new theater space with this seductive classic drama by August Strindberg in which bad behavior has never been so much fun. What’s a young noblewoman to do? There are so many rules and so little time. But Miss Julie doesn’t follow rules. She follows her heart and her happiness, regardless of the consequences. Directed by Jarrad Holbrook, featuring Barbra Andrews. Suzanne Favette and Matthew Blood-Smyth.

Showtimes: 7:30 p.m. Thursdays-Saturdays; 1:30 p.m. March 4 and 11

Note new location: 2810 Larimer St., 303-300-2210 or paragon’s home page

Backstage Theatre’s “Oscar and Felix”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through March 24: Neil Simon has updated his classic comedy “The Odd Couple,” bringing the trials of Felix Unger and Oscar Madison to the present day. Uptight, neat-freak Felix has been thrown out by his wife, and the only place he can stay is with his slob of a best friend, Oscar. The two worlds collide with comic results. Features an all-new setting with new jokes and new characters. Contains adult language.

Showtimes: 7:30 p.m. Thursdays through Saturdays; 2 p.m. Sundays

121 S. Ridge St., Breckenridge, 970-453-0199 or backstage’s home page

Firehouse’s “Coronado”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through March 24: This modern-day Greek tragicomedy by Dennis Lehane follows three intertwining tales: A boy and a girl fall in love while ransacking a rich man’s house during the waning days of the Vietnam War; a compromised psychiatrist confronts the unstable patient he slept with; and a father and a son wage a lethal battle of wits over the whereabouts of a stolen diamond and a missing woman. These tales take on national myths regarding class, gender, freedom and regeneration through violence – reveal a truth you may not expect.

Showtimes: 7:30 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays; 6:30 p.m. March 4 and 18

John Hand Theatre, 7653 E. 1st Pl., 303-562-3232 or firehouse’s home page

Theatre Out Denver’s “Southern Baptist Sissies”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through March 24, 2012: After a three-year dormancy, Theatre Group, Colorado’s first and longest-running theater company dedicated to telling gay stories, is coming back to life as Theatre Out Denver. “Southern Baptist Sissies,” a story about religion clashing with sexuality written by Del Shores, follows four gay boys and their struggles with the Baptist Church. Storyteller Mark Lee Fuller tries to create a world of love and acceptance in the church and clubs of Dallas while desperately trying to find a place to put his own pain and rage. The world Mark creates also includes two older barflies, Peanut and Odette, whose banter takes the audience from laughter to tragedy and tears. Theatre Group’s 2006 staging was awarded the Denver Post’s Ovation Award for best drama.

Showtimes: 8 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays

Crossroads Theatre, 2590 Washington St., 303-881-8173 or theatre out denver’s facebook page

Miners Alley Playhouse’s “Master Class”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through April 1: Terrence McNally’s award-winning musical play about Maria Callas takes us to one of her famous master classes where, late in her own career, she challenges the next generation to make the same sacrifices and dare to rise to the same heights she did, making her the most celebrated, the most reviled and the most controversial singer of her times.

Showtimes: 7:30 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays; 6 p.m. Sundays (except on the final Sunday, when the curtain is at 2 p.m.)

1224 Washington St., Golden, 303-935-3044 or map’s home page

Thunder River’s “The Cherry Orchard”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through March 10: Anton Chekov’s classic from a century ago presents themes of cultural futility: the aristocracy to maintain its status, the bourgeoisie to find meaning in its new-found materialism, and the rise of the middle class. The play’s influence is evident in the works of Eugene O’Neill. George Bernard Shaw and Arthur Miller.

Showtimes: 7:30 p.m. Thursdays through Saturdays; also 2 p.m. Feb. 25 and March 4

67 Promenade, Carbondale, 970-963-8200 or thunder river’s home page

Equinox Theatre Company’s “And Things that Go Bump in the Night”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through March 17: And you thought your family was weird. Ruby and her children, Lakme and Sigfired, have barricaded themselves in a cellar, fearful of the sinister world outside. Together, they lure “special visitors” to their home, only to be seduced, taunted, and ultimately destroyed. By Terrence McNally.

Showtimes: 7:30 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays

At the Bug Theatre, 3654 Navajo St., 720-984-0781 or equinox’s home page

Theatre ‘d Art’s “Mercury Fur”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through March 11: Enter the twisted mind of children’s book author Philip Ridley, who shows you the darker side of desperation as a dysfunctional family of teens does what it must in a post-apocalyptic world, where the streets are run by deviants and butterfly junkies. Survival is the commonality; fantasy is the commodity.

Showtimes: 8 p.m. Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays

At Osborne Studio Theatre on the University of Colorado-Colorado Springs campus. 719-357-8321, theatre ‘d art’s home page or email info@theatredart.org

Coal Creek Community Theater’s “Brighton Beach Memoirs”

Opening Friday, Feb. 24, through March 10: The first in Neil Simon’s semi-autobiographical series about Eugene Jerome is set in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, N.Y., in 1937. It is a coming-of-age comedy that focuses on a Polish-Jewish American teenager going through puberty, sexual awakening and a search for identity. Eugene is forced to handle growing up as he tries to deal with his extended family, including his parents and older brother.

Showtimes: 7:30 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays; 2 p.m. Sundays; also 7:30 p.m. Monday, March 5

Louisville Center for the Arts, 801 Grant St., Louisville, 303-665-0955 or coal creek’s home page

Now or Never’s “The Odyssey”

Saturday, Feb. 25, only: This adaptation of Homer’s epic poem integrates acting, shadow theatre, puppetry, masks, video projections and live music composed by Michael Stanwood in a unique blend of ancient and contemporary performance techniques. The performance is free.

Showtime: 2 p.m.

Canyon Theater at the Boulder Library, 1001 Arapahoe Ave., Boulder, 303-441-3100 or now or never’s home page

Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center’s “Life in a Marital Institution”

Saturday, Feb. 25, and Sunday, Feb. 26, only: James Braly ‘s poignant, darkly humorous autobiographical monologue is set in a hospice, where he sits at the bedside of his dying sister, who asks him to trade places with her. Until she realizes that would mean trading places with him: Being in his marriage (a fate worse than death). The narrative cuts back and forth between the hospice, where his sister is engaged to be married, and scenes from his marriage, exploring infidelity, near-death childbirth and other high-stakes yet comic adventures.

Showtimes: 8 p.m. Saturday and 2 p.m. Sunday

30 W. Dale St., 719-634-5583 or the fac’s home page

Complete theater listings, however you like them

Go to our complete list of every currently running production in Colorado, including summaries, run dates, addresses, phones and links to every company’s home page. Or check out our listings by company or by opening date

Compiled by John Moore, Special to The Denver Post
